The game itself is sublime. Each action is straight forward. The game NEVER felt like it was a drag as there’s always things to do to keep you preoccupied and the last few rounds are still exciting. I love the almost lack of downtime, for a heavy game like this. I love how the map feels tight between the four players, due to the way initial placement works. So it's unlike many games where you start at the edge and you all close in, rather it starts somewhere in the middle. So, you expand outwards if you want to be left alone (but the tiles will be less stellar). I love how fluid the movement feels - none of that plodding malarky on TI4 where your squadrons have to do this slow and plodding island hopping to capture planets. I don’t like that bit of TI4 and it’s just boring and uninteresting. Eclipse is the same the way it does territorial expansion, but it does it quicker. And, of course, I am very impressed at the game duration. The 30mins per player wasn’t that far off as we played 3-3.5 hours in a mostly first timers 4 player game.

What sucks is the exploration bit where the tiles are random. I like that it stays true to the 4X experience where you are really exploring the map, similar to Archipelago (unlike a lot 4X-ish games out there) But the tile draw can determine how well the player will do, and I don’t like that. So a few unlucky draws and you'll be lagging behind. And since this is a Euro with no safety nets, it becomes very difficult to catch up.

Random technology draw is very refreshing, but it is susceptible to turn-order problem if a certain tech is well-sought and you’re last on the turn order simply because the player on your left passed first.

Pro's:

1) The empire management aspect is incredibly intuitive.
2) Aesthetics and art style suits the genre with the iconography being very well designed.
3) The cold war style arms race of technology and ship upgrading while trying to counter what your opponent is doing. Many people complain that plasma missiles or whatever are overpowered, I have found that NOT to be the case in my games as long as I kept up the arms race.

Con's:

1) Randomness of tile drawing can make it feel like your empire stagnates at turn one. It's like you instantly lost the game.
2) Battles can feel like a long drawn out messy slog. It's supposed to be the culmination of the hard work you put into your empire and representative of your economic and technological power. In practice it feels more like a random dice fest without the parts that usually make that kind of combat fun.
3) Game will generally end just as things are about to ramp up. Kind of like listening to a song remixed by an idiot who cuts out the bit that everyone likes.
4) Setup time is a pain.
5) The bookkeeping/empire management part of this game is definitely well done from an intuitive point of view, but it slows the game down a lot and ends up being kind of disconnected from the 4X elements.

This is strictly from a thematic point of view. The game play is okay, but seems a bit cheesy for me.

I do like the tech advancements and the exploration. (Although there could be more exploration?)

It is entirely likely that who will win and loose will have been decided by turn three, only to have 3 more hours of tedious Sisyphean actions left before the game can finally end.

There are some excellent design choices here to be sure; I like how research and ship customization is handled in particular. Unfortunately they are buried under an avalanche of randomness and clunky combat mechanics.

----

Edit from the future: After more plays, I stand with my bitterness on this. For all its promises of grand operatic 4X empire management, the only thing that matters is getting lucky with exploration. Everything snowballs or deathspirals from there.

Eclipse features a staggering set of interlocking and yet elegant and streamlined mechanics encompassing exploration, economics, tech trees, diplomacy, unit construction and warfare logistics. It's also a mite on the random side, and all of these diverse elements funnel directly and inexorably towards the totally hands-off, tedious combat minigame that is easily the worst feature.

I really wanted to like this game. But the more i played it, the more i was bothered by the randomness in combat, and more significantly, the randomness in the tile draw. Different races seemed interesting at first, but got boring as each race has a relatively fixed strategy and varying too much from it leads to inefficiency. This in and of itself would not be a dealbreaker, as I enjoy many games which people call “scripted”, as these games often have a good meta-game. However, this one can be painful, bc the effectiveness of your strategy is heavily influenced by what tiles you draw (e.g. the descendants gain a ton from drawing many ancients hexes, whereas planta gains most from drawing “empty” hexes, etc). Still fun, but more than a little long for what it is and it’s too easy to find more immersive, satisfying games with a shorter play time. It was hyped as taking an epic space opera and condensing it into an evening, but in my opinion it took an average euro game core, tossed in some theme, and stretched it into a 3+ hour grindfest.

I had some friends who were quite into this one, and I'd never played, so it was worth a try.

Well, I guess it was =) I had pre-taught myself the game to save time... and that didn't really help much. Even though they all knew the game (it had been a year or since they played) and I was pretty comfortable getting going, the game lasted over four hours, and we hadn't even done the last round. We jokingly called it quits, as the second edition (we were playing the first) only has eight rounds.

I suspect the second edition would help with some of the aesthetics and bookkeeping and overall feel, but this junior 4x thing just didn't do it for me overall.

What I do like is the ship customization idea and the tech around that. That's fun. It's neat to slot in upgrades and build around a certain style of fleet. It's also cool to be able to build orbitals and starbases and things in your area that are more stationary. And the economy balance of money and resources can lead to an interesting cadence on your action board, where you have to make tough calls later on.

But boy, I can't really abide the randomness on the tiles just giving someone way more money or something. Money in particular just seems like this essential element for action economy and to avoid disaster in your game, so having more of it in resources really puts someone at an advantage. And the combat is just not great when extended out. It has some fun wrinkles if you were just doing one battle or something, but when it's just neverending die rolls for some train of combat, it just really kills the game flow. And while the glory tokens for battle kind of help some random little person have a successful combat by having a single ship die, and then they maybe pull a valuable VP chit, it's just a weird cadence later in the game having people cycle chips for minimal gain.

I dunno. I'd play again, but everything felt just too long, and I wish combat was more streamlined. And I also would've liked more of a diplomatic element to be baked into the game rather than just: "Hey, don't shoot me" or let's exchange these little ambassador tokens. Not a game I'd rush to play again.

Sitting through other players' battles can provide drama and amazing beat-the-odds results, but it's also time consuming and frequently uninteresting to non-combatants. I also don't like the tendency of my plays to have no combat till halfway through the game; and the slow crawl through the techs to tweak your ship for battles has just become rote. Nothing here is really the fault of the game, but after 25 plays, I'm just not interested in exploring the game any further, even with expansions.

JUN/13 - Strong mix of Euro systems and Ameritrash theme-based mechanics. I initially gave this a 10, but on a second playing bumped down a notch to a 9. As I was playing, I found the admittedly well-balanced resource system to be such a large part of the focus of the game that the game experience felt too Euro (read system heavy) for my desire for a theme-heavy game.

I think a $15 expansion that consisted of a deck of 60-100 encounter/event cards would turn this game from a 9 to an 11, and make it my favorite game ever. (Just looking at the first large expansion makes me think the Hive ships and new player mats would make for a 10-rated game).

JUL 2013. Still incredible game design. I just want a bit more theme in the way of non-player alien encounters and other events. That would nicely supercede the focus on the resource engine that drives so much of the game.

MAY 2014: Still a solid 9 for me. better with more players, obvs.

JUN 2014: Last play was only an 8 for me, but it was a combination of being tired, getting unlucky with early tile draws (Ancient hexes and a Draco neighbour), and having to teach the game to new players...again - which I find exhausting. In general, my enjoyment of the base game is an 8/9 depending on the group, and a 9/10 with the expansion.

22nd play:  DEC/14: I like the game with 4p, but Alliances have to be banned right now for us - 2 players with the best ship designs banded together to steam roll the other two of us, and is was distinctly less fun. Also, after the game ended, we removed the 7-9p techs out - they add too many power techs.

I personally love this game, and especially love all the choices players have to make. Should I expand early for a chance at the resources I need, even though my monetary upkeep costs will be higher for the rest of the game? Should I save up for a technology I really want, or buy one now that is less good but will allow me to progress in some way now? Should I specialise in one specific strand of technology, or try to cover all my bases?

The way that ships can be upgraded is especially nice. Each fleet feels unique from game to game, and players have to balance having a lot of fire power with being able to take a lot of damage. Do you go all in with the missiles tactic? Do you make a tank?

There are however a few small things I am not so keen on:
1. It can sometimes take too long to get through, especially near the end when everyone has a lot of ships and modifiers and combat can get tricky to do correctly.
2. The player mats have a lot of pieces balanced on them that can get knocked around easily - it would have been good to have indented spaces in thicker boards, to hold the cubes in place.
3. In my experience, the final round is invariably combat-heavy. It would have been nice to have a somewhat randomised end point, eg. to have a mechanism such as shuffling an end point card into the bottom of a stack of round cards, so players are expecting the game to end but are unsure when exactly and either have to take more risks or play more conservatively.

Overall, definitely a game that I am always keen to put on the table when me and my friends have a full day for it.

Eclipse would be very easy to describe as Through the Ages in space, and with a map. That might do a disservice to the complexities of Eclipse, but it's also bluntly accurate. The cube system from TtA works well here, supplemented by the addition of "bureaucracy discs", which are spent to push the governing and progressive limits of your empire. It is possible to lose the game around turn 5 or 6 out of 9, leaving you to carry out the motions of a futile game, but experience can mitigate this. The alien abilities are all unique, and all worth trying once. They must be especially commended for not making Humans just the vanilla race; they more than hold their own with their logistic speed and trade efficiency that you'll find yourself missing when playing any of the aliens.

After three plays, it's become clearer how to reduce setup and tear-down time, especially with only two players vying for ship upgrades instead of six. Setting out fewer tiles from the bags devoted to the initial parts or each row of upgrades also makes it less likely to knock a bunch of tiles over, as does having fewer orbital/monolith tokens out, as they're rarely used.

I wouldn't be invested in the setup and teardown time if I didn't want to come back to this game time and time again. The player boards are indeed lovely ways to minimize the mental bookkeeping for the resources that are available. Because this game has less diplomacy than others, it works better for our two-player games than other space-themed 4x games do.

So far, the one major improvement we all seem to need is the Quantum Grid. Without it, the action economy feels too constrained, and the scale of the game feels less epic. However, sometimes that's desirable, and when that tech isn't available, the game's tightness is palpable. It also makes different game sessions feel radically different, increasing the replayability in a lot of good ways. The 30 minutes per player play time seems tantalizing doable with more experience; we're probably at 40 minutes per player without emotional tumult.
